ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Inverse design and topology optimization of novel photonic crystal broadband passive devices for photonic integrated circuits

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: We report on the application of various optimization methods as a very promising simulation approach for the design of true integrated optical devices by means of inverse design. We show that these techniques provide a global optimum toward one or various functional objectives at a reasonable computational cost. The results obtained by these methods are far better than intuitive design procedures and clearly outperform trial-and-error based models. We illustrate their performance by using a series of inverse-designed practical photonic devices.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Photonic crystals (PC) have generated a surge of interest in the last decades as they offer the possibility to control the propagation of light to an unprecedented level. The prospect of attaining a fully functional photonic device that tackles light propagation in subwavelength scale requires breaking the spatial symmetry of PCs. These topologies enhance additional functionalities and enable a higher level of control in complex light paths. However, creating novel designs based upon aperiodic PC clusters entails dealing with numerous sensitive and correlated parameters. In addition, investigating all feasible combinations of structural parameters for a particular application demands a lot of computational effort, which scales exponentially with the number of parameters. Therefore, the challenging problem of designing such PC structures belongs to the class of nondeterministic polynomial time-complete (NPC) optimization problems.

Currently, the process of designing a PC structure that ultimately complies with a certain required objective is still based on intuitive assumptions rather than using a rigorous mathematical technique. However, designing structures founded on intuition, usually yields to nonoptimum results. Beyond these assumptions, creating PC structures that comply with multiple conflicting objectives highly hinders the design procedure.

In contrast with intuition-based approaches, we show in the present manuscript that global optimization heuristic and evolutionary algorithms are specially well suited for dealing with the noisy and nonlinear nature of partially disordered PCs. In this work, we report on a number of inverse designed novel passive devices using two alternative heuristic methods, namely the fast simulated annealing technique (FSA) [1] and the improved harmony search (IHS) [2] algorithm and an evolutionary algorithm called the Nondominated Sort Genetic Algorithm 2 (NSGA2) [3]. The optimized complex systems obtained by means of these techniques clearly outperform intuitive based models. These procedures support a constrained search of the parameter space, and hence they can yield PC topologies that are fully compatible with complementary metal-oxide semiconductor (CMOS) fabrication technology. We found that these methods are easily applicable to most of PC engineering design problems since they do not require any detailed knowledge of the structure of the problem and they can rely on the solver of the problem as a blackbox. Therefore, we exploit the advantages of implementing a stochastically-driven optimization process and the speed and accuracy of the finite element method (FEM) in order to design fully functional optical components, such as sharp bends in PC waveguides (PCWGs), compact power splitters, PCWG crossings and wavelength selective routing mechanisms, and high quality factor and reduced modal area cavities.

Section1.Heading: Optimization and inverse design
Section1.Para: The introduction of disorder in PCs allows one to tailor the flow of light through PC structures up to an unprecedented level. However, using a disordered PCs involves dealing with a hard scattering problem, and is extremely difficult to estimate the degree of disorder required for achieving a desired target property. Consequently, the traditional approach based on intuition limits the maximum number of degrees of freedom that can be dealt with to a number that makes it possible to explore the whole landscape of values of these parameters. From this landscape, the most appropriate structures are extracted.

This approach is computationally very costly and, often times, impractical. To quote an example, let us consider a simple PC model consisting of an arrangement of holes drilled in a dielectric material for which one must decide whether to fill a hole with bulk material or to leave it as it is in order to guide the light through a certain path. The amount of possible configurations grows exponentially fast as 2 N , where N is the number of holes in the structure. Therefore, even this simple case involves dealing with a large amount of possible configurations, which renders the problem unmanageable except for lattices with a few holes. There is an alternative approach that allows one to address this problem: the inverse design (ID) method. In the framework of the ID methods, one can set the goal functionally and, by means of a proper optimization engine, elucidates a structure that fulfills the required functionality.

In this manuscript, we use two heuristic algorithms as well as a genetic algorithm to devise passive photonic crystal devices for specific applications. These methods provide an excellent balance between the degree of complexity involved and the quality of the obtained results. When solving PC structures that are required to comply with a single objective, e.g., steer light through a curved path, we use two different heuristic approaches that are complementary, the FSA and the IHS algorithms, respectively.

The FSA method comes from the well-known simulated annealing technique (SA) [3], a very popular meta-heuristic ground state search method that has been commonly applied to combinatorial optimization (CO) problems. It aims to find the optimum state of a specific problem with nonzero probability for accepting uphill solutions using a dimensionless “temperature” parameter that follows the Metropolis [4] criterion. Our FSA algorithm shares many features with the original SA method, but it reduces significantly the required running time of the standard SA algorithm by performing a semilocal search, and it enhances the efficiency of the optimization process by further controlling the number of uphill moves. Furthermore, we have included a re-annealing scheme that helps to bind the search space of less sensitive parameters relative to the ranges of more sensitive parameters. This reannealing takes place every 100 iterations. In our simulations, the initial temperature is set to a typical value of 100.

The IHS algorithm, on the other hand, is inspired by the musical improvisation processes and a detailed description of the operators involved in the optimization can be found in [5]. IHS has been widely applied to a variety of combinatorial optimization problems [6–8]. However, the local search procedure of HS does not ensure a high performance [2]. In this context, Mahadavi et al. [2] proposed a new method for enhancing the local search and convergence of IHS through dynamic adaptation of both the pitch adjusting rate (PAR) and the bandwidth. In addition, we have included a further randomization operator proposed in [9]. For our studies, we have set an harmony memory size of 10 with an harmony consideration rate of 0.9, a pitch adjusting rate that goes from 0.4 to 0.9, together with a bandwidth that sweeps from the range of 0.0001 to 1 and a randomization rate of 0.1.

There are many situations where multiple simultaneous objectives must be fulfilled. Usually, there is no way to devise a PC structure that produces an optimum for each of the competing objectives. In these cases, multiobjective evolutionary algorithms (MOEAs) allows one to find multiple optimal solutions, in the Pareto sense [11], in a single run. This is a feature of a great practical importance for designing novel PC devices such as photonic crystal resonant cavities that possess a high Q factor and a low modal volume simultaneously or PC wavelength division multiplexers, just to cite some examples. In this paper, we use an elitist multiobjective evolutionary algorithm called non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm (NSGA-II) described in [3]. We applied this procedure for 500 generations with a population size of 50 genes.

Section2.Heading: Solving harmonic propagation using FEM
Section2.Para: FEM is a general purpose numerical method for solving partial differential equations that it is especially well suited for dealing with electromagnetic problems in geometries of arbitrary complexity. Recently, we have shown that FEM is a reliable and fast computational method for calculating important electromagnetic quantities in the stationary regime [10], such as the transmittance spectra in PC clusters. Furthermore, it combines very well with iterative processes such as the optimization methods described in previous sections. In this paper, we have used an approach consisting of optimizing a two-dimensional PC and, later, calculating the corresponding merit function (the transmittance mainly) for the corresponding 3D slab extruded from the 2D template. In a later work, we will report calculations performed directly on the PC slabs [12]. All the PC designs reported in the present work are based on a triangular lattice made of 0.35a radii holes drilled into a Si dielectric material, where a is the lattice parameter. Maxwell’s equations are scale-invariant, as long as absorption is not present, and thus, one can set an arbitrary value of the lattice constant a and express all distances in terms of this quantity. In this work, we use units in which a is unity. The index of refraction of the Si was set to 3.46 for the frequency range considered throughout this work.

Section1.Heading: Inverse designed PCWG sharp bends
Section1.Para:
The band gap guiding mechanism of PCs allows to create unprecedented waveguide curvatures while it preserves an efficient guiding along extremely sharp corners. This fact opens the possibility of building essential stages for novel integrated optoelectronics, small-scale all-optical circuits, and overall for semiconductor device miniaturization [13–16]. A simple 60∘ PC bend can be introduced in our initial triangular structure by removing half a row of holes in the Γ–K direction and another one in the Γ–M direction, as shown in Fig. 1a. Due to the existence of a PBG, light is confined to the bend region and no power will be radiated out of the waveguide. In the initial, non-optimized, bend structure, the discontinuity along the guiding path causes large reflections at the bend, and hence it provides low transmission (see Fig. 1). This due to the fact that the mismatch at the bend region excites higher order evanescent modes in the PC waveguide. The situation radically changes, however, when we apply our optimization algorithms to this waveguide. The resulting topologies obtained by using the IHS and FSA algorithms, respectively, are depicted in Fig. 1a–c. It can be seen that the optimized topologies present a significant improvement in the transmittance on the selected dimensionless frequency range from 0.26 to 0.28, as shown in Fig. 2. The structural modifications carried out by our heuristic algorithms result in a shift of the waveguide modes and yield to a better coupling of the energy from the Γ–M to the Γ–K direction waveguides. As a consequence, the bandwidth increases and the spectrum is flatter.

Section1.Heading: Inverse design of ultracompact Y-junction power splitters
Section1.Para: Standard PC splitters come in X and Y shapes, but these systems usually present high transmission losses. The Y-junction (or branch) configuration, in particular, has been commonly considered as having a very poor transmittance [17, 18]. This is mainly due to the existence of sharp 120∘ bends. However, in [12], we demonstrate that by means of these heuristic optimization methods, one can devise structures that minimize the reflections in curved waveguides even for systems requiring high bandwidth. In fact, when we apply our FSA and IHS optimization algorithms to an initially undistorted Y-junction structure, two new half-power splitting schemes are obtained, as shown in Fig. 1e and Fig. 1f. Although not shown here for the sake of brevity, these splitter configurations divide the input power equally at the output ports without significant reflection or radiation losses in the normalized frequency range [0.26–0.28]. Moreover, since they are built following the PC standards, they comply with the size compactness requirements of future PICs.

Section1.Heading: A photonic crystal line defect waveguide integrated with a multimode interference block (MMI) based power splitter
Section1.Para:
The Y-junction configurations presented in the previous section operate within a broad bandwidth; they present negligible losses, and they possess a very compact size. However, they require an additional sharp bend stage that further complicates the whole splitter design yielding to a very challenging structure. Alternatively, we have applied the inverse design technique to a different geometry that does not contain this inconvenience. This structure consists of three disjoint elements, namely an input waveguide, a short interference section (MMI block), and two symmetric output waveguides. In this configuration, the incoming field interacts with the interference stage in such a way that the field is split and redirected equally into both output waveguides. This structure allows to couple the split light power directly into the output ports, and thus, the overall design is simplified. Figure 3 depicts the power splitting of an incoming monochromatic field and the geometry of the inverse designed structure. Figure 4 shows that both algorithms succeed in the task of maximizing the half-splitting for both, the Y-junction and the MMI like splitting structures in the 0.26–0.28 frequency range, up to an extremely wide operating bandwidth that almost covers the entire passband of the selected guided mode. The maximization of the transmittance over frequency range 0.26–0.28 ensures that the transmittance losses due to the splitter mechanism are almost inhibited. Regarding the transmittance of the W1 PCWG, it should be pointed out that the amplitude of the transmittance of the isolated W1 PCWG lies below the theoretical value of 1. This fact is due to the presence of absorption boundaries surrounding the simulation domain.

Section2.Heading: Inverse design of an optical cross-connect and wavelength multiplexing structure
Section2.Para:
Optical cross-connect interconnects (OXC) are the key fundamental element for high-speed all-optical signal switching systems. We present a fully bidirectional wavelength division multiplexer (WDM) and OXC compatible with chip-scale silicon photonics. This device is made of two parallel PCWG sections joined by an inverse designed interference stage that produces a mode matching between opposite waveguides across a reasonable bandwidth. In addition, the most widespread configuration of add/drop multiplexing devices that, in general, are constructed including an array waveguide diffraction grating or fiber gratings, demand a significantly large bend radius, and so the overall device dimensions scale accordingly. Our simulations reveal that this component outperforms previous approaches, as it allows to couple waveguide modes using a short and compact PC geometry made of a few holes and allows to miniaturize the crossing and multiplexing functionalities, as shown in Fig. 5. Figure 6 depicts the transmittance spectrum calculated at the boundary of each output port. It can be seen that almost the entire input power is redirected through a unique port and, moreover, this structure changes this port according to the input signal wavelength. We believe that this system could serve as an optical signal encoding source for an optical code division multiple access system (OCDMA), since it allows for an efficient, low loss, and fast routing of WDM signals through an optical network architecture.

Section1.Heading: Inverse designed PC resonant cavities with high quality factor and reduced modal area
Section1.Para:
When the periodic lattice of a PC is intentionally broken by placing a point defect, there is the possibility to trap light at the defect. This exhibits two very important features with regards to designing novel functional devices: On the one hand, extremely high quality factors (Q) can be achieved and, on the other hand, the spatial localization of trapped modes within these cavities present extremely low mode volumes. Unfortunately, implementing both optimal criteria simultaneously is a challenging task, since both objectives are somewhat competing ones. We have investigated the possibility of using the NSGA-II MOEA algorithm in order to find topologies that optimize both objectives in a balanced way. In particular, we focused our research on structures presenting good criteria within donor state cavities. The starting geometry for these simulations is our standard 0.35a triangular lattice where one hole has been filled with bulk material. For these simulations, we used a simulated binary crossover (SBX) probability of 0.9 and a polynomial mutation probability of 0.03 as proposed in [3]. The optimization process of the NSGA-II run is schematically shown in Fig. 7, where the Pareto-front of these individuals evolve during the simulation. By means of this method, one gets multiple optimal solutions that ensure an overall optimization of both criteria. From these, one can choose the solution that better suits the requirements of each particular casuistry.

Two of the many resonant cavities investigated are depicted in the inset of Fig. 7, corresponding to a resonant cavity with a dipole aspect and a high Q value and a resonant cavity that is reminiscent of the whispering gallery mode observed in microdisk resonant cavities.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In this paper, we study the feasibility of using inverse design technique to devise high-efficient PC passive devices. We use both single objective heuristic algorithms, namely the FSA and IHS algorithms together with a MOEA algorithm called NSGA-II, for more challenging, multiobjective, designs. We report on sharp bend structures that exhibit a near 100 % intrinsic bending efficiency for a broad bandwidth, two alternative power splitter structures that equally divide the incoming power supply without significant reflection losses. In addition, we report on a cross-connect structure formed by two parallel PCWGs that simultaneously acts as a broadband WDM. Finally, we report on an elitist multiobjective genetic algorithm approach as a design tool for devising PC cavities that exhibit high quality factors and reduced modal areas simultaneously.
